Supporting Canadians through the pandemic with transformational learning

posted on October 21, 2020

We, as a department, have been talking for some time now about the importance of the ESDC Service Strategy, and that one of the core principles guiding us is remaining responsive to current and emerging client needs. This is an incredibly important approach, now more than ever.

It’s an understatement to say how unusual this year has been, but our response to Canadians in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic has proven how flexible and innovative we are as an organization when the going gets tough. How did our department do that? We feel strongly that one big factor is learning.

That said, much like you, we both try to incorporate learning into every aspect of our work and personal lives.

Mark Perlman’s take on learning: During the pandemic, most of us had to shift to a virtual work environment. One thing I have learned is that telephone conversations and meetings, while efficient, could never replace the face-to-face contact we were used to having in our intact team in the office. Non-verbal communication is essential to ensuring appropriate communications. I’ve had numerous staff tell me they miss seeing their colleagues, and didn’t realize how much they appreciated it. My team and I quickly embraced video conferencing and learned the ins and outs of MS Teams to allow us to have the virtual face-to-face contact, which has helped us continue to engage with each other, including sharing the odd laugh. I encourage everyone to learn and embrace this technology, and reach out, even if it is just to say “hello”. It goes a long way, and makes a huge difference!

Darlène de Gravina’s take on learning: Taking care of your own wellbeing, and being mindful of the wellbeing of your employees and colleagues is incredibly important, now more than ever. I make a point of dedicating time to read or listen to audiobooks and podcasts; this helps me to focus on my wellbeing, while also learning a bit more about a topic of interest or importance. To ensure I have the latest resources and guidance, I also reference the tools developed by our department, including the My Wellbeing – An Employee Guide During COVID-19. In keeping with Mark’s example, I also had to learn and adapt quickly to video technology in order to lead and participate in branch and corporate meetings. Within HRSB’s management team, we have regular MS Teams meetings. Video conferencing is always great, we get to see our colleagues “in person”, and everyone loves seeing my German Shepherd puppy Stella walk into the room to “participate” in a meeting (but really to ask for a treat or some attention).

Learning is incredibly important to help us, as public servants, adapt and further develop. To help guide us, the College@ESDC has provided the department with learning opportunities to increase our knowledge and skill sets in key areas, ranging from Design Thinking and Cognitive Flexibility, to Innovation and Transformational Leadership.

Move over eLearning@ESDC Bulletin, Connexion Corner is here!

On the heels of the eLearning@ESDC Bulletin, we are pleased to share that the College has transitioned to a new online, monthly learning bulletin called Connexion Corner that connects learners with meaningful, relevant learning at ESDC.

Similar to the eLearning@ESDC Bulletin, each edition of Connexion Corner features a learning theme that supports ESDC’s Learning Priorities. You can also find virtual learning offerings to fit your preferences, interests and needs. Through Connexion Corner you can:

  • discover what your ESDC colleagues are doing to improve how we work and provide services to Canadians;
  • consult Coco, our learning advice columnist; and,
  • transform learning into a team activity.

In light of this exciting announcement, we want to hear from you! How has learning helped you in your work during the pandemic? What are you planning to learn this year to push your learning further? Let us know in the comments section below!

 

Mark Perlman

Chief Financial Officer, Senior Assistant Deputy Minister and ESDC Learning Champion

Darlène de Gravina

Assistant Deputy Minister, Human Resources Services Branch and Student Network Champion

Darlène De Gravina, Mark Perlman

Creating new connections from isolation

posted on October 16, 2020

Sylvie Bérubé, Assistant Deputy Minister for Western Canada and Territories Region

Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, some of us remained in the office and some of us found new desks at home, but none of us were able to work and connect with our colleagues in the ways we did before. As some begin their gradual return to local offices, I am seeing that, despite self-isolation and physical distancing, we continue to find new ways to stay connected and share our experiences.

In June, I enjoyed the opportunity to meet virtually with over 560 staff in the Western Canada and Territories (W-T) Region through an Ask Me Live! online chat in collaboration with our national partners in the Transformation Management Branch. During that one-hour session, staff posed over 200 questions on a wide variety of topics. Questions ranged from addressing telework challenges, to maintaining mental health and work-life balance, from ensuring employee health and safety when returning to work sites, to what staff could do to reach out to and help their colleagues during these times.

It was rewarding to be able to read, absorb and share in the thoughts and ideas of staff in this open and candid two-way dialogue. Because the level of staff engagement was so strong, the hour flew by for me, and I was not able to get to every question asked. However, I made a commitment to address the most popular questions, and I am happy to say that a summary of the top ten thematic questions and my answers is available on iService. It is my hope that our region can keep the momentum going and continue this dialogue in many other ways in the future.

As I reflect upon this experience, a significant takeaway was a greater understanding that so many of us need a deeper connection with others. Our people are the steady drumbeat of our organization, and it is vital that we continue to engage in ways that allow us to adapt, connect and celebrate our achievements together. I was reminded of this at our recent nationwide commemoration of Public Service Pride Week. Although we could not celebrate in person, we were able to be together through virtual Zoom parties, video montages, virtual polls and online panel discussions.

The importance of nurturing our connections remains top of mind for me. I am optimistic that the lessons we are all learning will continue to help us in creating our “next normal” together and a future workplace where we can all flourish and thrive.

 

Sylvie Bérubé

Assistant Deputy Minister

W-T Region
